message: interested in hearing experiences of anyone working on a start up part-time while keeping a full time day job
legal/tax implications in UK
do you have to set up a company?

I am doing that. Not sure if everyone would be able to have the setup that I have.. I'm a contract Project Manager, I'm not busy, I use the office facilities to work on my startup like conference rooms, printers, software on the work computer.. I would say I do 2 hours of contract related work, and 6 hours of start-up work. But I continue billing 8 hours.

However, it's a compromise and a risk to your career. To maintain this slow paced workload here, I purposely do mediocre work - keep the ideas, contributions, and 'smart'ness to a low level. Just enough for them to want to keep you around, but not consider you for promotion.

I'll never fund a company founded by a "johnny5"... or work with one. Professional Ethics (and, frankly, old-fashioned integrity) are cornerstones to a successful start-up.  I currently work full-time at a $16B/yr company... which I don't enjoy all that much, but it pays the bills for me and the our start-ups my team and manage.  It's really about having a great team you can delegate to and TRUST! stamina and perseverance are also key... Don't expect to loaf around an watch tv nights an weekends.  Have plenty of passion and keep extra passion in reserves.  Our 4 start-ups are in various stages from mature to vapor-plans. Also across 4 distinctly diverse industries ensuring none of us get too burned out from one particular venture.  Taxes and legal is easy here in the states... I expense everything and file 1040 regular. Our immature start-ups are part of a blanket holding LLC while the mature ones graduate to their own legal entity (right now a C-Corp and another LLC).  Not sure if any of that was helpful, but that's how we do it here.... And most of us have day jobs.

I am doing just that. I work full-time for UPS Canada in their Brokerage Dept. from 4am to 1230pm Mon-Fri then after work for am usually on my laptop running http://www.HogWildHost.com with my business partner.  Its a lot of hard work and keeps your time management skills in check.
@Luke_Ubiquitous At the same time not all of us can simply afford to quit our full-time jobs as they pay the bills and help fund our startups.  We all have to start somewhere and somehow.

@futurespective to the 2nd part of your question, look up sole proprietorship under UK tax laws.  If you don't plan on partnering with anyone and it won't cost you much to run a website or webapp, you probably don't need to incorporate a company for your side business.
And obviously, get professional help or advice when you launch.  i.e. when you are ready to apply for incubation or partnership.  Hope this helps.
Typically not a great idea, but it does happen. Better off to quit and/or just consult.
